description: This paper examines the capacity of certain reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms to stitch together pieces of experience to solve tasks not seen during training, and investigates whether supervised learning (SL)-based RL methods possess this stitching property. It introduces new datasets to test this and proposes temporal data augmentation to improve generalization in SL-based RL methods.

title.value: Closing the Gap Between TD Learning and Supervised Learning – A Generalization Point of View
title.justification: This title encapsulates the core comparison between Temporal Difference (TD) learning in RL and Supervised Learning approaches, with a focus on generalization.
title.quote: Closing the Gap Between TD Learning and Supervised Learning – A Generalisation Point of View

type.justification: The paper includes both theoretical analysis and empirical results to support its claims.
type.quote: Our analysis shows that this sort of generalization is different from i.i.d. generalization. This connection between stitching and generalisation reveals why we should not expect SL-based RL methods to perform stitching, even in the limit of large datasets and models. Based on this analysis, we construct new datasets to explicitly test for this property, revealing that SL-based methods lack this stitching property and hence fail to perform combinatorial generalization.

research_field.justification: The research primarily focuses on RL, particularly the differences between TD learning and SL in the context of RL.
research_field.quote: Our work shows that combinatorial generalisation is also required to solve tasks in the context of RL.

sub_research_field.justification: The paper discusses the importance of goal-conditioned policies and their ability to generalize to new state-goal pairs during testing.
sub_research_field.quote: We will study the problem of goal-conditioned RL in a controlled Markov process with states s ∈ S and actions a ∈ A.

name.justification: DDPG is cited as another RL method that has the stitching property.
name.quote: The stitching property [5] is common among RL algorithms that perform dynamic programming (e.g., DQN [6], DDPG [7], TD3 [8], IQL [9]).

type.justification: DDPG applies deep learning to deterministic policy gradients in RL settings.

name.justification: The datasets are used for offline RL experiments in the paper.
name.quote: Our experiments reveal a subtle consideration with the common D4RL datasets [15]: while these datasets are purported to test for exactly this sort of combinatorial generalization, data analysis reveals that “unseen” (state, goal) pairs do actually appear in the dataset.

name.justification: The Offline Ant Maze dataset is used in the context of RL to evaluate the stitching property.
name.quote: In our experiments, we collect new offline datasets that precisely test for stitching (see Fig. 3 and Fig. 12 for visualisation).
We visualise our new image based and partially observable environment created using Miniworld

name.justification: The authors created new variants of the D4RL datasets to better test for combinatorial generalization.
name.quote: Thus, our experiments are run on a new variant of these datasets that we constructed for this paper to explicitly test for combinatorial generalization.

name.justification: The library is used for clustering states in the temporal data augmentation process.
name.quote: We use the k-means algorithm from scikit-learn [62] with the default parameters to group states together.
